postcontent:
I am very reluctantly putting this rifle up for sale. She-who-must-be-obeyed says it has to go if I want to equip the eldest with a competition rifle. So here we go

This rifle is of the older, better style with a 21.5 barrel and 18 round magazine. They arent making those anymore, unfortunately, due to idiotic laws limiting magazine capacity. So here we have a pre-ban plinking and small game rifle. This year in particular has a nice spring-loaded cap for the brass tube magazine, which locks into place positively. Unfortunately earlier models dont have positive lock. I guess that brass tube is a sought-after feature, since newer models dont have it.

Accuracy is exactly what one would expect of Marlins wonderful rimfire barrels, and the trigger has been worked on to break cleanly at 4 lbs. The squirrel stock is apparently becoming a sought-after option. This one has some scratches and dings, but feels very nice in the hand and comes to the shoulder beautifully for an adult. Of course it has the lovely lines this rifle is in part famous for. These traits combine to make this rifle feel like a real rifle, not a kids toy. The only real weakness with this rifle is the rear sight  I guess Marlin figured everyone would put scopes on these. Maybe theyre right, since the barrel seems to justify some optics. 

Im aware that one can buy a brand-new Model 60 for $170 or so, but it will be $200 by the time you pay for transfer and all that nonsense. Worse, you dont get the longer barrel or higher capacity, and youre stuck with a crappy plastic stock. This was made back when they made real rifles out of real wood.

this is a interesting luger it is a 1937 mauser s/42 it has the letters KU stamped after the receiver serial number..These markings indicate this was a gun put together by the Kriegoff company. The meaning of "Ku" has long been a subject of speculation, with most experts concluding that these were a late war Luftwaffe contract, that was assembled with substandard parts, hence the use of the "Ku" or "Kummerrer" markings behind the serial number, indicating leftover or mis-sized parts. While others have theorized that these were assembled by the Krieghoff factory using left over Mauser parts. In either case there were only approximately 5000 total produced making these fairly scarce.
